stem: A client with a large pericardial effusion is being monitored. Based on the documentation in the Hemodynamic & Cardiac Sound Log, which finding indicates the development of Cardiac Tamponade?

tabs.title: Cardiac Auscultation
tabs.content: Current: Heart sounds are noted to be 'heard as if from a great distance' and are rhythmically muffled. No murmurs or gallops noted.

tabs.title: Neck & Peripheral Exam
tabs.content: Neck: Jugular Vein Distension (JVD) noted even when the client is sitting up at 45 degrees. Lungs: Clear in all fields.

options.text: The progressive narrowing of the pulse pressure (diff between systolic and diastolic)
The increase in systolic blood pressure

rationale.correct: This is **Cardiac Tamponade (a1)**. While Muffled Heart Sounds and JVD are part of Beck's Triad, the **Narrowing Pulse Pressure (a1)** is one of the most critical and earliest hemodynamic shifts. As fluid fills the pericardium, it 'crushes' the heart, preventing the ventricles from filling (reducing SBP) and increasing the base pressure (maintaining DBP). This brings the two numbers closer and closer (104/86 -> 82/78). If the pulse pressure becomes zero, the heart cannot pump at all.
clinicalPearls: Beck's Triad: Big neck veins (JVD), Bad Blood Pressure (Low/Narrow), Buried Heart Sounds (Muffled).
Narrow Pulse Pressure = The heart is being 'squeezed' from the outside.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing JVD or Muffled sounds because they are 'on the list.'
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While all are correct in Beck's Triad, the **Trend of Pulse Pressure** is the most precise indicator of the *progression* of the tamponade in a 'Chart/Exhibit' style item.

mnemonic.title: Squeeze-Play
mnemonic.expansion: Fluid in the sac. Heart can't beat back. Pressure gets tight. Tamponade is in sight.
